title: England sweat over fitness of Billy Vunipola after he undergoes scan on ankle injury
text:
England are waiting nervously to hear the prognosis on Billy Vunipola after the star No 8 was sent for scans on an ankle injury.

Vunipola twisted his ankle during Saturday's victory over Argentina and was subsequently removed at half-time.

He is now doubtful for Saturday's final Pool C Test against France - and Eddie Jones will be praying that he is fit for the quarter-finals.

Billy Vunipola twisted his ankle during England's World Cup win over Argentina on Saturday

England have no specialist No 8 cover in their 31-man squad, although flankers Mark Wilson and Tom Curry have both previously filled in.

'Billy has had a scan and that is ongoing, and we will have a clearer picture tomorrow,' said assistant coach Neal Hatley.

'He is being assessed and that will go on throughout the day and we will see how he pulls up.

'We assessed him after the game and give him 24 hours to see where that gets him, so he has another 24 hours before we will make a firm diagnosis.

England No 8 Vunipola is now doubtful for Saturday's final Pool C Test against France

'He is walking around with a smile on his face. We will know a lot more on Tuesday and he did have a scan as a precaution.'

No one else in England's back-row offers Vunipola's ball-carrying physicality.

Hatley, however, is confident that England will not be short of fire power in the absence of the giant No 8.

'We plan for all eventualities and we have got with Ellis Genge, Mako Vunipola, Maro Itoje, Courtney Lawes and Kyle Sinckler,' said Hatley

Neal Hatley reveals England will have a clearer picture over Vunipola's injury on Tuesday

'People pick up the slack when Mako and Billy don't play. We have played a lot of rugby without them. Billy is an important figure for us, but other people pick up the slack.'

There were more positive injury updates on prop Joe Marler, who hobbled off during the victory in Tokyo.

'Joe has trained this morning and he has played a lot of rugby for us,' said Hatley. 'It's a position we have good strength in - and we will see how he pulls up to make sure we put out the strongest team possible. There is a little bit of referral in his back and we will see how he is tomorrow.'
